how is gas fee on boba:
Boba offers much lower gas fees than Ethereum, typically around 10 Gwei or less, due to its architecture. This can be paid using the native Boba token ($BOBA) or the gas token of the underlying blockchain. The actual gas price on Boba L2 is updated regularly, influenced by Ethereum L1 gas price changes, with a maximum percentage change of 5% to prevent sharp fluctuations. 
 Key Aspects of Boba Network Gas Fees: 
 Low Fees: Boba Network reduces Ethereum's high gas fees, making it more affordable to use. 
 Flexible Payment: You can pay for transactions using the native BOBA token or the underlying blockchain's native asset. 
 Dynamic Pricing: The gas price on Boba L2 adjusts based on Ethereum's gas price. 
 Stable Pricing: To ensure stability, the gas price on Boba L2 is capped, preventing drastic changes in a single update cycle.
how do i setup a node on boba?:
Running a node allows you to sync with the network, validate transactions, and interact with the blockchain independently. The official documentation recommends using Docker for simplicity, supporting execution engines like Geth or Erigon. This guide focuses on running a full non-sequencer node (the most common setup for operators). Note that Boba currently operates its own sequencer, so community nodes act as verifiers or full sync nodes without direct incentives in the current protocol release. 
 Prerequisites 
 Software: Docker and Docker Compose installed on your system (e.g., via official Docker docs for your OS). Git for cloning the repo. 
  Hardware: While not explicitly stated, expect at least 16-32 GB RAM, 2-4 CPU cores, and 1-2 TB SSD storage for mainnet snapshots (databases can exceed 500 GB). Use a stable internet connection for syncing. 
 Knowledge: Basic familiarity with command-line tools and blockchain concepts. 
 Warnings: 
Always verify downloaded snapshots using SHA256 checksums to avoid corrupted or malicious files. 
 Running a node consumes significant bandwidth and storage; monitor your setup. 
 For testnets (e.g., Boba Sepolia), use smaller snapshots for testing. 
 No protocol-level incentives exist for verifiers yet (e.g., no gas compensation for challenges), but future upgrades may introduce them. 
 Step 1: Clone the Repository 
 Open a terminal and run: 
 git clone https://github.com/bobanetwork/boba.git 
 cd boba/boba-community 
 This gives you access to Docker Compose files and configs for Boba networks. 
 Step 2: Configure Environment Variables 
 Copy the sample config: 
 cp .env.example .env 
 Edit .env with a text editor (e.g., nano .env or VS Code). Key variables include: 
 Node versions (check the software release page for latest tags). 
 RPC endpoints for L1 (e.g., Ethereum for Boba Ethereum).  
 Paths to data directories. 
 Descriptions in .env.example explain each; customize for mainnet or testnet. 
 Step 3: Download and Prepare Database Snapshots 
 Snapshots speed up syncing. Download based on your target network and engine (Geth or Erigon). Verify with sha256sum <filename> against hashes on the snapshot downloads page. 
Boba Mainnet (Erigon): 
 curl -o boba-mainnet-erigon-db-1149019.tgz -sL https://boba-db.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/mainnet/boba-mainnet-erigon-db-1149019.tgz 
 Boba Mainnet (Geth): 
 curl -o boba-mainnet-geth-db-114909.tgz -sL https://boba-db.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/mainnet/boba-mainnet-geth-db-114909.tgz 
 Boba Sepolia Testnet (Erigon): 
 curl -o boba-sepolia-erigon-db.tgz -sL https://boba-db.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/sepolia/boba-sepolia-erigon-db.tgz 
 Boba Sepolia Testnet (Geth): 
 curl -o boba-sepolia-geth-db.tgz -sL https://boba-db.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/sepolia/boba-sepolia-geth-db.tgz 
 Extract the snapshot (replace data.tgz with your file): 
  tar xvf data.tgz 
 This creates a data directory (e.g., /db). For OP Sepolia (if testing Optimism compatibility), use: 
 curl -o op-sepolia-genesis.json -sL https://networks.optimism.io/op-sepolia/genesis.json 
 erigon init --datadir=/db genesis.json 
 Build Erigon from source if needed: Clone https://github.com/bobanetwork/v3-erigon and run make erigon. 
 Step 4: Generate JWT Secret 
 This secures communication between execution and consensus layers: 
openssl rand -hex 32 > jwt-secret.txt 
 Step 5: Update Docker Volumes 
 Edit your docker-compose.yml (or network-specific file like docker-compose-mainnet-geth.yml) to mount volumes correctly. Example: 
services: 
  l2: 
    volumes: 
      - ./jwt-secret.txt:/config/jwt-secret.txt 
       - /path/to/your/db:/db  # Replace with your extracted data path 
  op-node: 
    volumes: 
       - ./jwt-secret.txt:/config/jwt-secret.txt 
       - /path/to/your/db:/db:ro  # Read-only for op-node 
 Step 6: Start the Node 
 Pull images and run in detached mode (-d). Use the appropriate Compose file. 
 Boba Mainnet with Geth: 
docker compose -f docker-compose-mainnet-geth.yml pull 
 docker compose -f docker-compose-mainnet-geth.yml up -d 
 Boba Mainnet with Erigon: 
 docker compose -f docker-compose-mainnet-erigon.yml pull 
 docker compose -f docker-compose-mainnet-erigon.yml up -d 
 Boba Sepolia Testnet with Geth: 
docker compose -f docker-compose-sepolia-geth.yml pull 
docker compose -f docker-compose-sepolia-geth.yml up -d 
Boba Sepolia Testnet with Erigon: 
docker compose -f docker-compose-sepolia-erigon.yml pull 
 docker compose -f docker-compose-sepolia-erigon.yml up -d 
The node will sync in the background. Monitor logs with docker compose logs -f. 
 Step 7: Verify and Monitor 
 Check sync status: Query your node's RPC endpoint (default: http://localhost:8545) via tools like curl or MetaMask. 
 Example health check: curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_blockNumber","params":[],"id":1}' http://localhost:8545 
 For issues: View logs (docker compose logs), ensure L1 RPC is accessible, and join Boba Discord for support. 
 Alternative: Run from Source 
If Docker isn't suitable, follow the Run a Node from Source guide for manual builds of Geth/Erigon and OP Node. 
 Node Types and Roles 
 Full Node: Syncs the entire chain (what this guide sets up); used for querying and light validation. 
Sequencer Node: Orders transactions (permissioned; Boba runs the only one currently). 
 Verifier Node: Challenges invalid state roots (no incentives deployed yet; rare use case). 
 For advanced setups (e.g., BobaBNB), check multichain docs. Always refer to the official node operators section for updates.
how secure is boba:
Boba Network uses an Optimistic Rollup Framework, a technology that bundles transactions off-chain and presumes them valid. This model leverages the underlying security of the base layer, such as Ethereum. Thus, each Boba deployment is as safe as the underlying blockchain. So long as the underlying blockchain itself is 'live' (not actively censoring transactions), Boba apps built on it are safe and secure. This security model is backed by a system of 'fraud proofs', whereby users are paid to reveal bad transaction results published to the Boba Optimistic based chain. Boba also utilizes a hybrid computing system to augment compute, which helps maintain the network's security.

what are the specific hardware specs for: Somnia validator nodes require hardware between Solana and Aptos specs: approximately 16-core CPU, 64GB RAM, 1TB NVMe SSD, and 1Gbps network bandwidth. Exact requirements may adjust post-mainnet, balancing accessibility and performance for 100+ global nodes.
how does boba's testnet handle spam tran: Somnia’s testnet mitigates spam through rate-limiting and gas fees, even in testing. The MultiStream protocol’s high throughput (1M+ TPS) absorbs spam attempts, while validator slashing deters malicious flooding. Testnet data shows resilience during 80M transaction spikes.
what type of encryption does boba use?: Somnia reportedly uses homomorphic encryption for secure data processing in privacy-sensitive dApps (e.g., DeFi or metaverse). This allows computations on encrypted data without decryption, though implementation details are sparse and await mainnet confirmation.
what metrics does boba's testnet dashboa: Somnia’s testnet dashboard tracks TPS, transaction volume (e.g., 3.6M total), unique addresses (300K+), validator uptime, and dApp activity (e.g., Chunked’s 80M daily txns). Real-time analytics help developers monitor performance and stress-test results.
how does boba support real-time gaming a: Somnia’s sub-second finality and 1M+ TPS enable real-time gaming via MultiStream’s parallel data processing. Games like Chunked leverage this for seamless multiplayer interactions, with low gas fees (<$0.01) ensuring cost-effective microtransactions.
what is the process for third party vali: Third-party validators apply via Somnia’s governance portal (post-mainnet), staking SOM tokens and meeting hardware specs. Testnet includes external validators for testing, with a vetting process to ensure geographic diversity and reliability.

how is the boba token governance?:
The Somnia governance system has 5 different groups: 
Token house - Token owners that primarily govern allocation of foundation and community tokens 
Validator council - Validators in control of hard forks, gas economics and network upgrades. 
 Developer council - Key developers that oversee the technology roadmap 
 User assembly - Key users who are used as a check and balance to other groups 
 Foundation board - Initially in control of the treasury and deployment of new code to the network. Eventually used as a conduit for the other participants and emergency overrides. 
 https://docs.boba.network/concepts/tokenomics/tokens-governance

why should i build on boba?: Boba, being an L2 has significantly lower gas fee than Ethereum, or even Binance. It not only helps Ethereum scale, but also allows contracts to tap into advanced off-chain compute capabilities that are not available on other chains. Boba also has an ecosystem fund to support early-stage projects that are just starting out and planning to launch interesting apps. This is in the form of grants programs, and incubators where promising developers are connected to credible investors.

how are cross chain messages relayed?:
Boba Network uses the eth-optimism message relayer, a service for relaying messages from L2 to L1. This service can also be used to relay fast messages for the L1CrossDomainMessengerFast without waiting for the dispute period. The message relayer uses L1MultiMessageRelayer/L1MultiMessageRelayerFast to relay messages together in batches.

can i skip the sequencer and directly su: Yes, it is possible to do so. You can submit transactions directly on L1 by calling 'enqueue()' on the Canonical Transaction Chain (CTC). The sequencer is forced to include your transaction on L2, but it still needs to be up and running.

what are the limits on hybrid compute we:
The following limits exist for the hybrid compute web2 calls 
 1. limits strings returned from external endpoints to 322 characters (5*64+2=322). 
 2. allows only one Turing call per execution. 
 3. imposes a 1200 ms timeout on API responses. Hence, please make sure that API responds promptly. If using AWS, note that some of their services take several seconds to spin up from a 'coldstart', and could result in persistent failure of the first call to the intended endpoint.
